title: A Meta-Analysis of Relations Between Achievement and Self-Concept
abstract: According to the internal/external frame of reference model, academic achievement has a strong impact on people's self-concept, both within and between subjects. We conducted a series of meta-analyses of k = 505 data sets containing the six bivariate correlations between achievement and selfconcept in two subjects. Negative paths from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept, indicating dimensional comparison effects, were strongest when the subjects were dissimilar with regard to the math-verbal continuum, reduced but still significantly negative when both subjects belonged to the verbal domain, and near-zero when both subjects belonged to the math/science domain. Additionally, we found stronger positive paths from achievements to corresponding self-concepts, indicating social comparison effects, and stronger dimensional comparison effects for grades than for standardized test scores, and for older rather than younger students. We extend dimensional comparison theory by discussing these results with particular regard to the nonexistence of assimilation effects, the effects of subject similarity on dimensional comparison effects, and other moderators of dimensional comparison effects.

abstract.text: According to the internal/external frame of reference model, academic achievement has a strong impact on people's self-concept, both within and between subjects. We conducted a series of meta-analyses of k = 505 data sets containing the six bivariate correlations between achievement and selfconcept in two subjects. Negative paths from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept, indicating dimensional comparison effects, were strongest when the subjects were dissimilar with regard to the math-verbal continuum, reduced but still significantly negative when both subjects belonged to the verbal domain, and near-zero when both subjects belonged to the math/science domain. Additionally, we found stronger positive paths from achievements to corresponding self-concepts, indicating social comparison effects, and stronger dimensional comparison effects for grades than for standardized test scores, and for older rather than younger students. We extend dimensional comparison theory by discussing these results with particular regard to the nonexistence of assimilation effects, the effects of subject similarity on dimensional comparison effects, and other moderators of dimensional comparison effects.

body_text.text: . Social comparisons use others as interindividual standards in order to judge the self (Festinger, 1954; Gerber et al., 2018) , whereas temporal comparisons use former achievements as intraindividual standards (Albert, 1977; Wilson & Ross, 2000) , and dimensional comparisons use other domains as intraindividual standards (Möller & Köller, 2001a; Möller & Marsh, 2013) . In recent years, research on the juxtaposition of dimensional and social comparisons has become more and more salient in education research as well as in some other disciplines such as social psychology (see Strickhouser & Zell, 2015) and sport psychology (see Chanal et al., 2009) .

This research built on the internal/external frame of reference (I/E) model of Marsh (1986) , which explains the findings of high correlations between mathematics achievement and achievement in the first language (L1) subject, in contrast to low correlations between mathematics and L1 self-concepts under the impact of social and dimensional comparisons (see below). The purpose of this article is to present the results of a meta-analysis of all studies that report empirical findings on social and dimensional comparisons concerning achievement and academic self-concept in two different subjects. In the theoretical section of this article, we discuss the I/E model (Marsh, 1986) , dimensional comparison theory (DCT; Möller & Marsh, 2013) , and the generalized I/E model (Möller et al., 2016) . In the empirical section, we subsequently present a meta-analytic approach summarizing the empirical findings on the relations between achievement and self-concept. The meta-analysis answers the question of how various moderators, such as different subject combinations, achievement measure types, and participants' age, affect the relations between achievement and self-concept.

The I/E model's finding that mathematics and L1 achievement usually show high positive correlations with each other, whereas correlations between mathematics and L1 self-concept typically are much lower (Marsh, 1986 (Marsh, , 1990b ) is counterintuitive, given that achievement in a particular domain usually is highly positively correlated to one's self-concept in the respective domain (Hansford & Hattie, 1982) . Considering the high correlation between achievement in different domains and between achievement and self-concept in the same domain, one would be inclined to expect self-concept in different domains to be highly correlated also.

According to the I/E model, when forming their ability self-concept in mathematics and L1, students compare their levels of academic achievement in the two domains by using two different but connected frames of reference: an internal and an external frame. Within an external frame of reference, students conduct social comparisons by comparing their accomplishments in a domain with their classmates' accomplishments in the same domain (e.g., "How good am I in math compared to my classmates?"). Within an internal frame of reference, they conduct dimensional comparisons (Möller & Köller, 2001a) by comparing their achievement in mathematics and L1 (e.g., "How good am I in math compared with English?"). Thus, academic self-concept in the two subjects is based on the information provided by these external and internal comparisons. For example, if a student's L1 achievement is higher than the average achievement of their classmates, their L1 self-concept will likely also be higher (social comparison). However, if their mathematics achievement is still higher than their L1 achievement, their L1 self-concept will likely be somewhat lower (dimensional comparison) .

Dimensional comparison processes have been drawn on to explain the domain specificity of academic self-concept and the often very low correlations observed between L1 and mathematics self-concept. Through such dimensional comparisons, talented students may develop only an average self-concept in their intraindividually worse subject, even though their performance in this subject is well above the average performance of their peers.

The I/E model assumes that the joint effects of social and dimensional comparisons lead to positive paths of achievement on corresponding self-concepts (interpreted as social comparison effects) and to negative paths of achievement on noncorresponding self-concepts (interpreted as dimensional comparison effects). However, it is worth noting that cognitive processes other than social comparisons may contribute to the strong relations between achievement and corresponding self-concept, for example, objective performance information (i.e., assessed independently of others' achievements; see also Chiu, 2012) . Additionally, we note that the interpretation of cross-sectional data do not allow for drawing causal conclusions. Notwithstanding this, following the tradition of the I/E model research, in this article, we designate the paths from achievement to corresponding self-concepts as social comparison effects and the paths from achievement to noncorresponding self-concepts as dimensional comparison effects, while bearing in mind that these effects do not necessarily imply causality.

The I/E model assumptions have been replicated in numerous studies. They were generalizable across gender, different age-groups , ability groups (Möller, Streblow, et al., 2009) , different ways of measuring achievement (e.g., Marsh & Yeung, 2001 ) and of measuring self-concept (Wolff et al., 2020; , and in different cultures or countries (Chiu, 2008 (Chiu, , 2012 Marsh & Hau, 2004) . Individual studies suggested that the I/E model can be generalized to age-groups ranging from later elementary school children (Lohbeck & Möller, 2017) to university students (Marsh, 1990a) . Furthermore, the I/E model assumptions have been substantiated in cross-sectional (Marsh & Hau, 2004) , longitudinal (Marsh & Köller, 2004; Möller & Köller, 2001b; Möller, Retelsdorf, et al., 2011; Möller et al., 2014; Niepel et al., 2014) , diary (Möller & Husemann, 2006) , and experimental studies Müller-Kalthoff, Jansen, et al., 2017; .

In a previous meta-analysis investigated 67 studies that focused on the relations between mathematics and L1 achievement and self-concept measures. The average correlation between mathematics achievement and L1 achievement was strongly positive and much higher than the average correlation between mathematics and L1 self-concept. More important, concerning social and dimensional comparison processes, are the four comparison effects: The two social comparison effects, leading from mathematics achievement to mathematics self-concept and from L1 achievement to L1 self-concept, were substantially positive, whereas the two dimensional comparison effects, leading from L1 achievement to mathematics self-concept and mathematics achievement to L1 self-concept, were substantially negative.

Several moderators were analyzed for their influence on the relations between achievements and both corresponding and noncorresponding self-concepts, as well as between achievements and between self-concepts. The strength of relations between L1 and mathematics achievement, as well as between achievement and corresponding self-concept, was moderated first by achievement measure type. Whereas the correlation between mathematics and L1 achievement was larger for standardized test scores than for teacher-assigned grades, the effect of achievement on self-concept was larger for grades, implying that grades are a more immediate source of achievement feedback for students when they are forming their selfconcept. Second, the type of self-concept measure moderated the relations: The coefficients of achievement on corresponding self-concept and the mathematics and L1 self-concept correlations were stronger when researchers used measures of self-efficacy, rather than ability self-concept. Subsequent to the meta-analysis of 2009, self-efficacy was no longer used in studies on the I/E model. Therefore, we did not apply self-concept measure as a moderator in our meta-analysis. Third, the correlation between self-concepts decreased with increasing age, thereby corroborating the assumption that general self-concept becomes more differentiated with age, as several self-concept dimensions emerge (see Marsh & Ayotte, 2003; Skaalvik & Valas, 1999) . The relation between achievement and noncorresponding self-concept did not change with growing age. However, there were only a few studies with elementary school children. Fourth, region of residence and fifth the percentage of girls/boys in the study samples did not affect the effect sizes. Sixth, sample size only affected the relations between achievements and between math achievement and verbal self-concept, with somewhat larger effects when samples were smaller. Finally, for publication year, correlations between mathematics and L1 achievement, and between self-concepts in the two domains, were larger in older studies than in more recent studies.

Overall, Möller, Pohlmann, et al.'s (2009) previous meta-analysis supported the conclusion drawn from the included single data sets that the I/E model is an adequate description of achievement-self-concept relations for different student populations in diverse countries. However, a substantial body of research on I/E relations between different variables has been conducted since the publication of this meta-analysis. As a result, some limitations of the Möller, Pohlmann, et al.'s (2009) meta-analysis have become apparent, from the standpoint of subsequent research findings: The analysis dealt exclusively with self-evaluations of mathematics and L1 achievement (Möller et al., 2016) . Since then, as proposed in the newly developed DCT (Möller & Marsh, 2013) , researchers have examined an important extension: the extension to domains other than mathematics and L1. DCT suggests that the effects of dimensional comparisons are not limited to selfevaluations of mathematics and L1 achievement but can also be expected for other combinations of (academic) disciplines. This extension is the central part of the present meta-analysis. It enables us to answer the question of whether the relations described in the I/E model are also valid for subjects other than math and L1, in particular, for subjects more similar than math and L1-as discussed in the following section.

Social comparison theory (Festinger, 1954) , temporal comparison theory (Albert, 1977) , and DCT (Möller & Marsh, 2013) are theories about the wellresearched cognitive processes performed by individuals to form their self-concept. Among the "Big Three of comparative judgment" (Müller-Kalthoff, , dimensional comparisons are of particular importance in the I/E model. DCT is based on empirical findings from introspective, path-analytic, and experimental studies on dimensional comparisons. It addresses the prevalence, the antecedents, and the consequences of dimensional comparisons. Additionally, it deals with the motivational basis for dimensional comparisons (suggesting a self-differentiation motivation; see , the integration of dimensional comparison processes into recent social cognitive approaches, and the interdependence of dimensional, social, and temporal comparisons. DCT's extension of the I/E model to domains other than math and L1 is most important for the present meta-analysis; this extension is part of the generalization of the I/E model. Whereas the classic I/E model is restricted to mathematics and L1 achievement and mathematics and L1 self-concept, DCT opens this logic up to a variety of other variables. Thus, recent research on DCT has yielded a generalized I/E model (GI/E model; Möller et al., 2016) . According to this GI/E model, a person conducts dimensional comparisons when comparing his or her perceptions of aspects of a particular domain A with his or her perceptions of aspects of a particular domain B, and this has consequences for various self-perceptions related to these domains.
body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: In initial approaches testing the GI/E model, some studies extended the classic I/E model to other subjects, and used a variety of subject-specific achievement and self-concept measures in domains such as science and second language (L2; e.g., Jansen et al., 2015; Marsh, Lüdtke, et al., 2015) or history . These studies stimulated a further look at the impact of dimensional comparison, and the distinction between dimensional contrast and assimilation effects. Contrast effects occur when achievement in one subject has a negative impact on a noncorresponding self-concept, whereas assimilation effects occur when achievement in one subject has a positive impact on a noncorresponding selfconcept. Following DCT, dimensional comparison led to contrast effects in selfevaluations when the respective abilities are believed to be negatively correlated (Hypothesis VI of DCT; see Möller et al., 2015) , and to assimilation effects in self-evaluations when the respective abilities are believed to be positively correlated (Hypothesis VII of DCT).
body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: According to DCT, the emergence of contrast versus assimilation effects is a result of the degree of similarity of the subjects that are being compared with each other. In most studies testing the GI/E model, the similarity between two subjects was based on their relative location on the "math-verbal continuum" (Marsh, 1990b) , on which domain-specific academic self-concepts are assumed to be located, with mathematics and L1 self-concepts at either end and with self-concepts for other school subjects (e.g., foreign languages, biology, history) located between these poles. Dimensional comparisons between subjects in which self-concepts are located relatively far from each other are called "far comparisons." Comparisons between subjects in which each self-concept is relatively close to the other are called "near comparisons." DCT assumes that far comparisons, such as those between mathematics and L1 achievement in the classic I/E model studies, lead to dimensional contrast effects. In contrast, near comparisons, such as those between L1 and L2 or mathematics and physics, are assumed to lead to weaker contrast effects or even to positive (assimilative) effects.
body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: Empirical studies on the GI/E model revealed heterogeneous findings regarding near-dimensional comparisons within the verbal domain. Although the results were in some cases nonsignificant, both assimilation effects and (somewhat more frequently) contrast effects have been found Arens et al., 2020; Brunner et al., 2010; Dickhäuser, 2003; Marsh et al., 2014; Marsh, Lüdtke, et al., 2015; Marsh & Yeung, 2001; Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, & Köller, 2006; Niepel et al., 2014; Xu et al., 2013) . The direction and strength of dimensional comparison effects for two subjects of the math/science domain have been shown to depend on the specific subjects being compared. Whereas contrast effects were found for comparisons between mathematics and science (in TIMSS [Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study] 2007 ; see Chiu, 2008 Chiu, , 2012 , there were usually small assimilation effects for comparisons between mathematics, physics, and chemistry, although these were not always significant Jansen et al., 2015; Marsh, Lüdtke, et al., 2015; Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, & Köller, 2006) . Heterogeneous, but often nonsignificant, effects emerged when biology was considered in combination with mathematics and verbal subjects (Jansen et al., 2015 Nagy et al., 2006) .

cite_spans.text: [Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study] 2007

body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: In one of the first studies testing the GI/E model with different subjects, Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, and Köller (2006) found near-zero dimensional comparison effects within the verbal domain and positive effects within the math/science domain. Most of the effects of comparisons between two dissimilar subjects were clearly contrastive. Similarly, analyzing comparison effects across five academic domains, Jansen et al. (2015) showed negative coefficients of mathematics, physics, and chemistry achievement on German (L1) self-concept. Most of the relations between achievement and self-concept related to mathematics, physics, and chemistry were in turn (significantly or nonsignificantly) positive, implying small assimilation effects. In another recent study, Marsh, Lüdtke, et al. (2015) demonstrated positive mean path coefficients for near comparisons and negative mean path coefficients for far comparisons. Marsh et al. (2014) revealed similar results, with small assimilation effects for two verbal subjects, Dutch as L1 and English as L2. Such results supported the central hypotheses of DCT: that far comparisons lead to strong contrast effects, but near comparisons lead to much weaker contrast or even assimilation effects. In contrast, some other studies have revealed contrasting relations between mathematics and science, although these are relatively similar subjects (Chiu, 2008 (Chiu, , 2012 . To date, the question as to which similar subjects produce small contrast effects and which produce assimilation effects remains open.
body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: In addition to the results of these studies on the GI/E model, indicating that perceived similarity of school subjects might affect the outcomes of dimensional comparisons, there is more specific empirical evidence supporting this assumption: found that stronger beliefs in a negative correlation between mathematics and L1 ability led to more negative path coefficients from grades in mathematics (L1) to academic self-concept in L1 (mathematics). Helm et al. (2016) experimentally induced a similarity or dissimilarity focus in students asked to compare pairs of school subjects such as mathematics and L1, mathematics and physics, and L1 and L2. They found stronger differences between students' self-concept measures in the subjects compared when students looked for dissimilarities between subjects than when they looked for similarities. Hence, perceived subject similarity-in in the form of beliefs about similarity in underlying abilities and in Helm et al. (2016) in the form of beliefs about similarities like difficulty, interestingness, or importance of the subject-seems to influence dimensional comparison outcomes. Yet, until now, there has been no meta-analytical overview of the dimensional comparison effects that emerge when subjects that are supposedly different, other than just mathematics and L1, are compared.
body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: On the basis of the assumption of DCT that dimensional (and social) comparisons of achievement may have broader cognitive, affective, and motivational consequences, the GI/E model also allows for the integration of self-perception variables other than self-concept. In this regard, the GI/E model assumptions were demonstrated for subjective task value components (Arens et al., 2017; Gaspard et al., 2018; Götz et al., 2008; , student-teacher relations , and interest (Schurtz et al., 2014) . These studies substantiated the existence of dimensional comparison effects of achievement in one domain on any kind of task value component in nonmatching standard domains. Although the comparison effects were weaker than in studies examining the effects on students' self-concept, it appeared to be the case that social and dimensional comparisons also influenced subjective task values (see Wigfield, Eccles, & Möller, in press ). However, given the small number of studies investigating the relations of achievement and subjective task value components that are suggestive of social and dimensional comparisons, it would seem premature to analyze these relations meta-analytically. Therefore, in the present meta-analysis, we confined ourselves to examining the relations between achievement and selfconcept. In particular, we focused on the relations between dissimilar and similar subjects. As noted above, the most obvious restriction of the classic I/E model is its limitation to the two domains of mathematics and L1, thereby excluding the majority of other school subjects.
body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: By including many more data sets than the 2009 study, referring to different subject combinations, the present meta-analysis overcomes this restriction. Furthermore, it significantly contributes to the discussion within self-concept research, as it has several theoretical and practical implications. With regard to its theoretical implications, the meta-analysis seeks to answer the question of whether dimensional comparisons always lead to contrast effects, or whether and under what conditions they lead to assimilation effects. To address this question, we analyzed the moderating role of the particular subject combinations and the (dis)similarity of the subjects; thus, the results of our study should allow a specification of DCT. Moreover, knowledge about whether dimensional comparisons lead to contrast or assimilation effects has important practical implications. For example, such knowledge allows teachers and parents to gain a better understanding of the development of students' self-concepts and thus to support students in the development of a positive self-concept.
body_text.section: Dimensional Comparison Theory and the Generalized I/E Model

body_text.text: The central approach of the present meta-analysis went far beyond that of the earlier meta-analysis by in at least four respects. First, it updated the 2009 meta-analysis by integrating all studies that researchers have carried out since then. Second, it overcame the restricted focus on mathematics and L1 by extending the I/E model to all subject combinations analyzed in the respective empirical research. Third, it systematically compared the relations proposed by DCT and the GI/E model for far and near comparisons. Fourth, with regard to those extensions considering the assumptions of DCT and the GI/E model, we evaluated whether potential moderators influence the relations between achievement and self-concept. Meta-analysts often differentiate between potential moderators worth considering for theoretical reasons (here, subject similarity and subject combination, types of achievement measure, years in school, and school type) and moderators that need to be explored for methodological reasons or for reasons of completeness (here, more subjects than mathematics and L1 being assessed in the study, gender distribution, region of residence, publication year, sample sizes, and author). In the following subsections, we elaborate on these moderators and derive hypotheses for the moderators considered worthy (for theoretical reasons) of being tested in the meta-analysis. In respect of the combination of subjects from the math/science and verbal domains, the central predictions of the present meta-analyses were derived from the classic I/E model: Hypothesis 1: High positive correlations between achievements in subjects from the math/science and verbal domains. Hypothesis 2: Moderate to zero correlations between self-concept measures in subjects from the math/science and verbal domains. Hypothesis 3: High positive path coefficients from achievement in math/science (verbal) domain to math/science (verbal) self-concept. Hypothesis 4: Moderate negative path coefficients from achievement in subjects in the math/science (verbal) domain to verbal (math/science) self-concept.

Subjects can be placed in greater or lesser proximity to each other on the mathverbal continuum. In line with the assumptions of the GI/E model, and the empirical studies mentioned above, we assumed the following moderating effects of subject similarity:

Hypothesis 5: Moderate negative path coefficients from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept when two subjects are dissimilar (i.e., one subject is mathematics or is close to mathematics, the other subject is L1 or is close to L1 on the math-verbal continuum), as in the classic I/E model with mathematics and L1 (specification of Hypothesis 4).

Hypothesis 6: Smaller negative, possibly positive, path coefficients from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept when two subjects are similar (i.e., both subjects belong to the verbal domain, such as L1 and L2, or both subjects belong to the math/science domain, such as mathematics and physics).

In addition to the impact of general subject similarity, we were interested in the relations between achievement and self-concept with respect to all specific subject combinations. For example, analyzing the subject combination mathematics/ physics might reveal different relations than analyzing the subject combination mathematics/biology, although both subject combinations belong to the math/science domain. Biology taught in school seems less similar to math than to physics (see Haag & Götz, 2012) . However, as we found only a few studies dealing with these subject combinations, we conducted exploratory analyses rather than formulating specific predictions. Hansford and Hattie (1982) found that teacher-assigned grades are more positively correlated to self-concept than are standardized test results (see also Marsh, 1990a) . The earlier meta-analysis of the I/E model found similar results. More specifically, it revealed that the positive paths from achievement to self-concept within the domains were stronger when grades were used as the achievement indicators. In addition, it showed that correlations between mathematics and L1 achievement were substantially higher when these were based on test scores instead of grades. Cross-domain path coefficients were not moderated by achievement measure type in the former meta-analysis. However, more recently, Marsh et al. (2014) revealed moderating effects of achievement measures on the social and dimensional comparison effects in the I/E model. Therefore, we tested the moderating effect of type of achievement measure on the comparison effects in the I/E model once more, using a larger data set. We predicted the following:

Hypothesis 7: Lower achievement correlations, stronger positive path coefficients from achievement to corresponding self-concepts, and stronger negative path coefficients from achievement to noncorresponding self-concepts for teacher-assigned grades than for standardized test results.

Studies testing the I/E model with elementary school children (i.e., Ehm et al., 2014; Möller, Kuska, et al., 2011; Pinxten et al., 2015) were inconsistent in terms of the size of the achievement-self-concept relations measured across different grade levels. However, subsequently to the metaanalysis, several further I/E model studies have dealt with elementary school children, and it was still of interest to determine whether a meta-analytic overview will reveal social and dimensional comparison effects for younger elementary school students. According to prior empirical findings, we predicted the following:
body_text.section: Years in School and School Type

body_text.text: Hypothesis 8: Higher self-concept correlations, smaller positive path coefficients from achievement to corresponding self-concepts, and smaller negative path coefficients from achievement to noncorresponding self-concepts for younger students compared with older students and for elementary school students compared with secondary school students.
body_text.section: Years in School and School Type

body_text.text: Further moderators are analyzed for explorative reasons, without specific hypotheses. They are described in the section "Variables and Moderators."
body_text.section: Years in School and School Type

body_text.text: All available studies that provided the six correlation coefficients between achievement in Subject 1, achievement in Subject 2, self-concept in Subject 1, and self-concept in Subject 2 were included in our analysis. We developed an extensive coding sheet to summarize the coefficients in the I/E and GI/E models and to thoroughly investigate possible moderation effects (see below). We employed elaborate meta-analytical methods to test whether the potential moderators affected the parameters of the I/E model.

The correlational studies had to meet several criteria to be included: indicators of achievement in at least two domains, indicators of self-concept in the same two domains, correlations between the four variables, and field data from educational settings (K-12). Thus, a study was only eligible for inclusion if it reported all six bivariate correlations that form the basis for the estimation of the I/E model: correlations between (1) achievement in Subject 1 and achievement in Subject 2, (2) self-concept in Subject 1 and self-concept in Subject 2, (3) achievement in Subject 1 and self-concept in Subject 1, (4) achievement in Subject 2 and self-concept in Subject 2, (5) achievement in Subject 1 and self-concept in Subject 2, and (6) achievement in Subject 2 and self-concept in Subject 2. These six correlations served as the basis of our meta-analysis.

For the acquisition of literature, we were able to build on our extensive familiarity with the research field and the existing meta-analysis of the I/E model . Reports on studies using the same samples as in a previous study were eliminated from all analyses, such as a German study by Lüdtke et al. (2002) , using a subsample of national results from the PISA study. The literature search for the period up to the end of 2006 revealed the former 63 references used in and four new references, leading to 67 references in all in the period up to this time. We replicated the literature acquisition with studies published between 2007 and the end of April 2018. To update the search procedure, we used the electronic sources PsycINFO, PSYNDEXplus, Data Citation Index, MEDLINE, Wiley Online Library, PubMed PsycLIT, the Educational Resources Information Center (ERIC), and the Social Sciences Citation Index (search terms "academic self-concept*" OR "self-concept* of abilit*" OR "abilit* self-concept * ") AND ("achievement*" OR "grade*" OR "test*" OR "performance*") OR ("I E model" OR "dimensional comparison*"). The total number of potentially relevant published and unpublished papers was 3,874. After screening on titles and abstracts of studies, we retrieved 386 references for full-text screening. We excluded all papers with studies that contained only the achievement-self-concept correlation in one subject. Additionally, we excluded all experimental studies (e.g., Strickhouser & Zell, 2015) , introspective studies (e.g., Möller & Husemann, 2006) , and all studies asking participants to infer the self-concepts of fictitious students (e.g., Müller-Kalthoff, Jansen, et al., 2017) . Furthermore, data sets dealing with teachers', parents', or classmates' ratings of students' self-concepts (e.g., Dai, 2002) were excluded. Ultimately, 54 studies met the inclusion criteria. Figure 1 illustrates the literature search and screening procedure. Together with the studies from the former meta-analysis, overall we integrated 121 (67 + 54) studies for meta-analysis, including k = 505

single data sets containing the six bivariate correlations between achievements and self-concepts. The specific number of data sets (defined as units including the six correlations) and participants varied for the different moderator analyses (see "Data Analysis" section for an explanation). Supplemental Table S1 (in the online version of the journal) depicts the number of data sets and participants for the different moderators where at least four data sets were available: When studies on the classic I/E model using only mathematics and L1 as subjects were integrated, there were 118 data sets, with 213,121 participants. Where studies on all subjects were integrated, there were 207 data sets, with 810,340 participants. All the studies contained at least one data set allowing testing of the I/E model patterns.

Two coders, working independently, retrieved the coefficients from the studies and coded each study along the dimensions (1) subject similarity and subject combination, (2) type of achievement measure, (3) years in school and school type, (4) additional subjects, (5) gender distribution, (6) region of residence, (7) publication year, (8) sample size, and (9) author. The transparent categories led to perfect intercoder agreement. Supplemental Table S2 (in the online version of the journal) gives a descriptive overview of the single studies and the included moderators.

We included only studies directly relating to academic achievement in at least two subjects. Reports focusing on standardized achievement tests were included, as were those using grades assigned by teachers. In contrast to the meta-analysis, which only used studies with mathematics and L1 as subjects, we included studies measuring achievement in any particular school subject. A subject was considered the first subject when it was either mathematics or was more similar to mathematics than the other subject, in respect of the math-verbal continuum. This continuum was defined as ranging from mathematics (math pole) via physics, chemistry, science, biology, physical education, and history, through to L2 and L1 (verbal pole). A subject was treated as the second subject when it was either L1 or was more similar to L1 than the other subject, in respect of the math-verbal continuum.

We included only studies relating directly to students' self-reports of their capability. Measures were any self-concept questionnaires. Items in each case tapped students' self-evaluations of achievement in the first subject.

Subjects were coded twice. In the first coding, three categories were built: dissimilar (first subject being from the math/science domain: mathematics, physics, chemistry, biology, or science; second subject from the more verbal domains: L1, L2, history, or physical education); similar math (both subjects being from the math/science domain), and similar verbal (both subjects being from the verbal domain).

In the second coding, all subject combinations presented in the papers (Subject 1/Subject 2) were analyzed (see Supplemental Table S2 for the different combinations of the single subjects). The mathematics/L1 combination served as the comparison standard or reference.

Studies were coded to reflect whether their achievement measures were teacher based-for example, regular grades or teacher evaluations of students' domainspecific ability ("school")-or consisted of standardized test procedures applied by researchers or other educational services ("test"). Studies implementing both types of achievement indicators were meta-analyzed separately, and each correlation pattern contributed to the respective analysis.
School year served as a continuous variable.
Studies were coded with regard to the school types: elementary school and secondary school.

We differentiated between those studies only analyzing students' achievement and self-concept in mathematics and L1, and studies including additional subjects, to analyze whether dealing with additional subjects affected the relations between achievement and self-concept in mathematics and L1.
Percentage of females served as a continuous variable.
We coded whether the sample was from Europe, Asia, Australia, North America, South America, or different countries.
Publication year served as a continuous variable.
Sample size served as a continuous variable.

Meta-analyses increasingly include authors or research groups as moderators to examine whether or to what extent effects generalize beyond the original research group. Therefore, we calculated an additional moderator analysis, distinguishing between studies with versus without Herb Marsh as (co)author.

We started by performing a meta-analysis without any moderator variables (null model), followed by moderator analyses for each moderator (e.g., subject similarity, type of achievement measure). All analyses were conducted within the statistical computing environment R (R Development Core Team, 2016).

More specifically, our approach proceeded in two steps: In the first step, we aggregated those correlation matrices that stemmed from the same sample and that did not differ with respect to the moderator of interest (see Lipsey & Wilson, 2001) . To this end, we used the weighted average (weighted by sample size; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004) . As pointed out by O'Mara et al. (2006) , this procedure minimizes the dependence that is due to the fact that data stem from the same sample, but at the same time preserves as much of the information as possible (see also . Imagine a study in which multiple I/E models that differed with respect to the two school subjects to be compared (e.g., mathematics/English vs. physics/chemistry) were fitted to data stemming from the same sample. To prepare the data for estimation of the null model, we aggregated the correlation matrices underlying these different applications of the I/E model. However, when our aim was to conduct a moderator analysis to study the impact of subject similarity on the I/E model, we did not aggregate these correlation matrices but entered them separately into the meta-analysis. After the aggregation of correlation matrices according to the procedure described above, we estimated the parameters of the I/E model for each aggregated correlation matrix by fitting a path model to the correlation matrix, using OpenMx software (Boker et al., 2017) .

Note that where the path analysis was conducted with an aggregated correlation matrix, we used the average sample size N (averaged over the respective Ns) as the sample size. However, because OpenMx requires correlations to be positive definite, this was not unproblematic, particularly where OpenMx was used with an aggregated correlation matrix. We used one technique that allows for mitigation of this problem, suggested by Yuan and Chan (2008; see also Yuan & Chan, 2016) . This technique adds a small value a to the main diagonal of the nonpositive definite matrix R: R′ = R + a × I, where I is the identity matrix. We proceeded as follows: We first checked whether an aggregated correlation matrix was nonpositive definite. If this were the case (<5% of cases), we applied Yuan and Chan's (2008) technique to that correlation matrix and subjected the "cured" correlation matrix to OpenMx. If the aggregated correlation matrix turned out to be positive definite, it was passed directly to OpenMx.

After the parameters of each path analysis were estimated, we extracted their sampling covariance matrix and subjected both the standardized parameter estimates and their sampling covariance matrix to multivariate meta-analyses. We first estimated a random-effects model without any moderators (i.e., the null model), which is essentially a multilevel model, using the R package metaSEM (Cheung, 2019b) . Applying the common notation for hierarchical models (e.g., Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002) , the following relationship held at the first level of that model:
EQUATION

body_text.text: where t i is the 6 × 1 vector of the point estimates of the parameters estimated from correlation matrix i, θ i is the 6 × 1 vector of the respective population parameters, and e i is the 6 × 1 vector of the deviations of the point estimates from their population parameters, which is multivariate normally distributed with the 6 × 6 sampling covariance matrix V i . At the second level, the model reads as follows:
Level 2: MVN θ θ i i i u u T = + ,~( , ) 0 (2)

where θ is the 6 × 1 vector of the "averages" of the population parameters and u i is the 6 × 1 vector of the deviations of θ i from θ, which is multivariate normally distributed with the 6 × 6 covariance matrix T. The random effects model (Equations 1 and 2) was used to pool the estimates of the parameters, taking into account the variability across data sets. As suggested by Overton (1998) , this model should be the preferred choice in meta-analysis. Note that the approach that we used in the present meta-analysis (i.e., pooling multiple path analyses; see Becker & Wu, 2007; Gasparrini et al., 2012) had several advantages over the alternative approach, of conducting the path analysis on the pooled correlation matrix. For example, it allowed for addressing the question of how the parameters (e.g., the path from achievement in one subject to self-concept in the other) of the I/E model varied across data sets. However, most important, it allowed us to investigate the influence of continuous moderators (e.g., gender distribution) on the parameters of the I/E model. The moderator analyses were conducted by estimating mixed-effects models for each of the moderators. In cases where a continuous moderator was investigated, we first standardized the moderator and then added it as a predictor to the second level of the model in Equation 2:
Level 2: MVN θ θ γ i i i i M u u T = + + ,~( , ) 0 (3)

where γ is the 6 × 1 vector of the slopes of the moderator M i . For discrete moderators with m categories, we first created m − 1 dummy variables C 1 , . . . , C m−1 , which were then added as predictors:
