body_text.text: where γ k (k = 1, . . . , m − 1) is the 6 × 1 vector of the differences between the parameters for the reference category and the parameters for the category that is coded by C k . It is interesting to note that the two main criticisms (see Cheung, 2015) that have been advanced against the stepwise approach used here do not apply to the present study. First, we did not face the problem of conducting path analyses on incomplete correlation matrices, because in each study, all of the six correlations that formed the basis for estimating the I/E model were observed. Second, all the results of the path analyses could be viewed as valid, because the path models were just identified (i.e., models with zero degrees of freedom) and fitted the data perfectly.

We calculated I 2 as an indicator of heterogeneity for the null models and R 2 as an indicator of the explained variance by a moderator (e.g., Cheung, 2019a) . As Cheung (2015) pointed out, I 2 is the proportion of the total variation of effect sizes that is due to between-study heterogeneity. When I 2 is above 75%, heterogeneity is high and justifies moderator analyses (Higgins et al., 2003) . Because of the large sample sizes of the studies included in our meta-analyses, and the small sampling errors, I 2 was high (>95%) for all null models, thus justifying moderator analyses. R 2 (the proportion of variance explained by a moderator) is interpreted as an indicator of the relevance of the moderator for the particular effect size.

Additionally, we analyzed whether the path coefficients of our central moderators remained robust when we controlled for other moderators. More specifically, we controlled statistically for type of achievement measure (similarity) when analyzing the moderator similarity (type of achievement measure, respectively). Table S1 gives an overview of the number of data sets and participants included in the particular analyses. All studies were on relatively young sample groups (elementary school to high school students). It is to be noted that the number of data sets integrated into the particular analyses shifts in accordance with the particular research question.

In this model, we included all studies dealing with achievement and domainspecific self-concept in mathematics and L1. A total of k = 118 independent data sets with n = 213,121 participants were found to analyze the classic I/E model relations between mathematics and L1 achievement and self-concept. This was an increase of k = 49 data sets (71%) compared with the meta-analysis. Table 1 shows the main results for all independent samples. We start the description on the left side of the table, with the correlations between achievements and between self-concepts with respect to Hypotheses 1 and 2. As expected, the average correlation between achievements was positive (r = .56), indicating a strong effect size. With the exception of one single study with high-ability students (Plucker & Stocking, 2001) , all correlation coefficients between both achievements were significantly positive, indicating relatively high achievement correlations for subjects on the endpoints of the math-verbal continuum.

The average self-concept correlation was r = .07, indicating a small positive relation. The self-concept correlations were substantially lower than the achievement correlations. Therefore, Hypotheses 1 and 2 of the I/E model were supported in the comprehensive meta-analyses.

We found an average path coefficient of β = .57 between mathematics achievement and mathematics self-concept and an average path coefficient of β = .46 between L1 achievement and L1 self-concept. Both of these effect sizes indicate strong social comparison effects, similar to those reported by Hansford and Hattie (1982) , and a little stronger than those in the meta-analysis. Most important for DCT, both path coefficients of subject achievement on noncorresponding self-concept (indicating dimensional comparison effects) were significantly negative (β = −.17 from mathematics achievement to L1 self-concept, β = −.20 from L1 achievement to mathematics self-concept), thereby replicating the most prominent dimensional comparison effects and the size of these contrast effects, in the meta-analysis. Therefore, our extended meta-analysis revealed strong support for the classic I/E model assumptions, on the basis of a much larger database, and supported Hypothesis 3 on the effects of social comparisons and Hypothesis 4 on the effects of dimensional comparisons for these subjects. The null model indicated significant heterogeneity, with I 2 > .94 for all six path coefficients, thus justifying moderator analyses.

To achieve an initial impression of the role of subject similarity, the 26 singlesubject combinations were divided into three groups (see Table 2 ). Combinations of one subject from math/science and one subject from the verbal domain were categorized as dissimilar (e.g., the combination mathematics/L2). Combinations of two subjects from the verbal domain were categorized as similar verbal (e.g., the combination L2/L1). Combinations of two subjects from the math/science domain were categorized as similar math (e.g., the combination mathematics/ biology). Table 2 depicts k = 124 data sets including dissimilar subjects, k = 15 including similar subjects from the verbal domain, and k = 14 data sets including similar subjects from the math/science domain. In additional analyses (see Supplemental Table S3 in the online version of the journal), we also controlled for type of achievement measure (grade vs. test score).

In Table 2 , the dissimilar group served as the reference group. The relations between dissimilar subjects were quite similar to the I/E model pattern in Table 1 : The intercept showed a high positive correlation between achievements (r = .55) and low positive correlation between self-concepts (r = .08). The path analyses revealed strong positive paths from achievement to corresponding self-concepts (β = .55, β = .46), and lower but substantially negative paths from achievement to noncorresponding self-concepts (β = −.16, β = −.19). Therefore, the results supported Hypothesis 5 on the effects of dimensional comparisons for dissimilar subjects.

When controlling for type of achievement measure, we had 65 data sets using test results and 70 data sets using grades. Results were quite similar for dimensional comparison effects with substantially negative paths from achievements to noncorresponding self-concepts for grades and for test results (all −.19 ≤ β ≤ −.15, all p < .001). The path analyses revealed weaker positive paths from achievement to self-concept within subjects for test results (β = .48, β = .40) than for grades (β = .62, β = .51). The intercept showed higher positive achievement correlations for test results (r = .64) than for grades (r = .47), and similarly low positive self-concept correlations for studies with test results (r = .10) and with grades (r = .08). Note. All subjects; Ach1 = Achievement Subject 1 (nearer to mathematics), Ach2
= Achievement Subject 2 (nearer to L1), SC1
= Self-concept Subject 1; SC2 = Self-concept Subject 2; Dissimilar = one subject from the math/science domain and one subject from the verbal domain; Ve/Ve = two verbal subjects;

Ma/Ma = two subjects from the math/science domain; Est. = estimate; SE = standard error; τ 2 = residual variance; R 2 = proportion of variance explained by the moderator; I 2 = indicator of heterogeneity. Table 2 illustrates the differences between this reference group (the dissimilar subjects) and the two study groups with similar subjects (upper part of the table) and gives absolute effect sizes for the similar subject groups (lower part of the table). In the row below the intercept of Table 2 , a nonsignificant slope of Δr = −.08 is presented, indicating the difference between the intercept or reference (r = .55) and mean achievement correlation between two verbal subjects (of r = .47; see second last row of Table 2 ). Therefore, the achievement correlations between dissimilar subjects and similar verbal subjects were not significantly different from each other. Table 2 also reveals that the average self-concept correlation was significantly different (Δr = .16) between both groups of studies: When two subjects from the verbal domain were included in the primary studies, the average self-concept correlation (r = .24) was significantly higher than for two dissimilar subjects. There was one significantly higher positive path coefficient from achievement to corresponding self-concept and, most important for DCT, two significantly less-negative path coefficients to the respective noncorresponding self-concept (all Δβ = .08). Hence, Hypothesis 6 found support: Within the verbal domain, the path coefficients on noncorresponding self-concept measures were less negative for near comparisons than for far comparisons. However, both cross-domain effects remained significantly negative, still indicating contrast effects of dimensional comparisons between two subjects from the verbal domain (β = −.09, β = −.11).

When controlling for type of achievement measure, there were only two data sets with test results, but 14 using grades. However, results were quite similar for dimensional comparison effects, with significant negative paths from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept for grades and for test results (all −.11 ≤ β ≤ −.08, all p < .05). The path analyses revealed weaker positive paths from achievement to self-concept within subjects for test results (β = .48, β = .44) than for grades (β = .62, β = .55). The intercept showed higher positive achievement correlations for test results (r = .62) than for grades (r = .44), and similarly strong positive self-concept correlations for studies with test results (r = .26) and with grades (r = .24).

Compared with the dissimilar subject combination, the similar math category delivered similar achievement correlations, higher self-concept correlations (Δr = .34, r = .42), and significantly lower dimensional comparison effects (Δβ = .10, Δβ = .16), leading to nonsignificant near-zero paths from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept (β = −.06, β = −.03, ns).

We had only five studies with test results, but 11 with grades. When controlling for type of achievement measure, results revealed near-zero paths from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept for grades and for test results (all −.05 ≤ β ≤ −.02, ns). Path analyses showed weaker positive paths from achievement to self-concept within subjects for test results (β = .38, β = .35) than for grades (β = .52, β = .46). The intercept showed higher positive achievement correlations for test results (r = .70) than for grades (r = .53), and similarly positive self-concept correlations for studies with test results (r = .44) and with grades (r = .41).

Subject similarity served as an important moderator of the relations between achievement and self-concept variables. Differentiating between dissimilar and two groups of similar subjects increased the explained variance for correlations between self-concepts (R 2 = 24%), and both cross-domain paths (R 2 = 8%, R 2 = 15%). To sum up, the typical I/E model pattern was shown to be valid for dissimilar subject combinations (supporting Hypothesis 5) and for two subjects from the verbal domain. In contrast, the dimensional comparison effects were close to zero when two subjects of the math/science domain were considered. There were no assimilation effects, even when both subjects belonged to the same domain. In line with Hypothesis 6, there were lower negative effects of achievement on noncorresponding self-concept when two subjects were similar.

A second measure of the role of subject similarity was achieved through consideration of all analyzed subject combinations. In this meta-analysis, k = 207 data sets (with n = 810,340 participants) using different subject combinations and self-concept measures were included. In the following sections, we only refer to subject combinations in detail where at least four data sets were meta-analyzed. This was the case for the 10 combinations mathematics/L1, mathematics/L2, mathematics/biology, mathematics/physics, physics/L1, physics/L2, physics/ biology, biology/L1, biology/L2, and L2/L1. The analyses with other subject combinations should be treated with caution however, since it is not necessarily the case that the conclusions can be considered very reliable.

The results for the 10 subject combinations are presented in Table 3 . We used the prototypical mathematics/L1 combination as the reference combination (intercept). Table 3 outlines the differences between this reference and the nine singlesubject combinations (upper part of the table) and the absolute effect sizes for the single-subject combinations (lower part of the table).

The pattern of relations for mathematics/L2 was quite similar to mathematics/ L1, except for significantly lower achievement correlations (Δr = −.18, r = .39) and a significantly more positive relation between L2 achievement and L2 selfconcept (Δβ = .12, β = .58) compared with L1 achievement and L1 self-concept (β = .46), indicating stronger social comparison effects for foreign languages than for the L1. There were no other differences, and in particular, there were no significant differences for the dimensional comparison effects, which remained significantly negative (β = −.15 for mathematics achievement on L2 self-concept; β = −.17 for L1 achievement on mathematics self-concept). Therefore, we found strong support for the GI/E model assumptions for mathematics and foreign languages.

The only significant difference to the reference group was the smaller negative path coefficient from biology achievement to mathematics self-concept (Δβ = .11, β = −.09), which was not in this case significant. Mathematics/Physics The subject combination mathematics/physics is particularly interesting, as some studies revealed dimensional assimilation effects between mathematics and physics. Indeed, there were significantly less negative and even small positive (but nonsignificant) effects for the cross-paths (Δβ = .19, β = .02 and Δβ = .23, β = .03), as well as significantly stronger self-concept correlations (Δr = .43, r = .50). Therefore, dimensional contrast effects diminished, and small and nonsignificant assimilation effects were revealed.

The pattern of results for the subject combination of physics/L1 only differed from the mathematics/L1 combination with regard to the substantially lower achievement correlations (Δr = −.20, r = .36).

Similar to physics/L1, the subject combination of physics/L2 differed from the mathematics/L1 combination with regard to the substantially lower achievement correlations (Δr = −.18, r = .38). Moreover, there were stronger achievement self-concept relations for L2 (Δr = .11, r = .57).

The subject combination physics and biology revealed significantly higher self-concept correlations (Δr = .18, r = .27) and a significantly smaller positive path coefficient from physics achievement on physics self-concept (Δβ = −.13, β = .43), compared with the reference combination. Both cross-path coefficients were smaller and not significantly different from zero (Δβ = .12, β = −.06 and Δβ = .15, β = −.05). Hence, dimensional contrast effects diminished.

There were significantly smaller negative cross-path coefficients from L1 achievement to biology self-concept (Δβ = .13, β = −.07, ns). Additionally, the subject combination of biology/L1 revealed higher self-concept correlations (Δr = .18, r = .26).

The pattern of relations for biology/L2 did not differ significantly from mathematics/L1. Since the cross-path coefficient from biology to L2 self-concept was marginally reduced, the path coefficient in this case was not significant (Δβ = .09, β = −.09).

There was only one subject combination within the verbal domain that had a sufficient number of data sets: The subject combination L2/L1 referred to the relations between a second and the first language. It revealed significantly stronger self-concept correlations than the mathematics/L1 combination (Δr = .18, r = .26), and a stronger path coefficient from L2 achievement on L2 self-concept compared with mathematics (Δβ = .08, β = .64). Most important, the analyses revealed smaller negative cross-path coefficients, indicating smaller but still significant contrast effects (Δβ = .08, β = −.10 and Δβ = .06, β = −.13) between the two languages.

Like subject similarity, subject combination served as an important moderator of the relations between achievement and self-concept variables. It increased the explained variance for all effect sizes between R 2 = 22% and R 2 = 38%. To sum up, the typical I/E model pattern, with significant positive path coefficients within subjects (social comparisons) and significant negative path coefficients across subjects (dimensional comparisons) was replicated for the combinations of mathematics/L1, mathematics/L2, physics/L1, physics/L2, and L2/L1. The cross-path coefficients of the combinations of biology with L1, L2, mathematics, and physics were also negative, but only two of these were significant (mathematics on biology and L2 on biology). For the combination of mathematics and physics, the dimensional comparison effects were positive but close to zero. There were no assimilation effects, even where both subjects belonged to the same domain.

Approximately half of the k = 139 data sets with n = 507,787 participants used grades (k = 72); the other half used test scores (k = 67) as achievement indicators (some data sets included both types of achievement measures). As outlined in Table 4 , the correlations between both achievements were significantly smaller for teacher-assigned grades (Δr = −.17, r = .48) than for standardized tests (r = .65). Path coefficients from achievements on the corresponding selfconcepts were higher when achievement was operationalized with grades (Δβ = .11, β = .60; Δβ = .09, β = .50) than when achievement was operationalized with standardized test results (β = .48, β = .40); this supported Hypothesis 7. There were no significant differences as a function of type of achievement measure, either with regard to the cross-path coefficients or with regard to the self-concept correlations. Differentiating between grades and test scores increased the explained variance for the achievement correlation (R 2 = 23%), and the withindomain path coefficients (R 2 = 14%, R 2 = 13%).

Since it was possible that the type of achievement measure was confounded with the subject combinations used in the single studies, we carried out additional analyses with the subject combination mathematics/L1 only. Results were quite similar, albeit with smaller correlations associated with both teacher-assigned grades than with the test scores: Path coefficients from achievements to corresponding self-concepts were higher for grades than for test scores; there were no differences between test scores and grades with regard to the negative cross-path coefficients and to the self-concept correlations.

The continuous moderator years in school, with k = 149 data sets including n = 551,590 participants, was related to the magnitude of all effects, except for the achievement correlations, and increased the explained variance between R 2 = 5% and R 2 = 18% (see Table 5 ). The older the students, the stronger were the positive paths indicating social comparisons. Moreover, the self-concept correlations were lower for older students. Years in school showed a significant moderating effect on the path coefficients of achievement on noncorresponding self-concept: The dimensional comparison effects became more negative for older students. These results were in accordance with Hypothesis 8 but contradicted the results of , who found no association between age and dimensional comparison effects. The results from these analyses for the subject combination of mathematics and L1 were quite similar: The path coefficients indicating social and dimensional comparison effects were stronger and the self-concept correlations were lower with increasing age. Table 6 shows the relations for different school types: k = 15 data sets from elementary school were compared with k = 113 data sets with secondary school students. We found the typical pattern of social and dimensional comparison effects for both elementary and secondary school students. However, the path coefficients from achievements to corresponding self-concepts were slightly stronger in the analysis with secondary school students (Δβ = .13 and Δβ = .07). Both dimensional comparison effects were more negative for secondary school students (both Δβ = −.07), whereas their self-concept correlations were reduced (Δr = −.14, Hypothesis 8). The achievement correlation remained stable between the school types. Differentiating between elementary and secondary schools increased the explained variance for the self-concept correlation (R 2 = 5%), and the within-domain paths (R 2 = 7% and R 2 = 2%).
body_text.section: Years in School and School Type

body_text.text: To sum up, our analysis revealed that both social and dimensional comparison effects were stronger, and self-concept was more differentiated with growing age and transition to secondary school. The results from rerunning these analyses for the subject combination of mathematics and L1 only were quite similar: stronger path coefficients indicating social and dimensional comparison effects and lower self-concept correlations being associated with growing age.
body_text.section: Years in School and School Type

body_text.text: To analyze whether including additional subjects in a study affected the relations between achievement and self-concept in mathematics and L1, we compared studies only asking for students' mathematics and L1 achievement and self-concept, with studies in which additional subjects were included. Supplemental Table S4 (in the online version of the journal) shows the relations between mathematics and L1 achievement and self-concept in 18 data sets dealing with more than mathematics and L1, compared with the 106 data sets considering mathematics and L1 only. The intercept showed that the mean mathematics/L1 achievement correlation in studies without additional subjects was r = .58, whereas the mean mathematics/L1 self-concept correlation was r = .09. In the row below the intercept, a significant slope is presented as the difference between the intercept and the correlation when additional subjects are included (Δr = −.17), resulting in a mean achievement correlation of r = .41 (last row of Supplemental Table S4 ). Therefore, the achievement correlation between mathematics and L1 was lower in studies dealing with additional subjects. Including the moderator increased the explained variance by R 2 = 9%. Supplemental Table S4 also reveals that the average self-concept correlation was not significantly different between both groups of studies, but when considering only those studies integrating more subjects than just mathematics and L1, the average self-concept correlation was no longer significant. Furthermore, Supplemental Table S4 shows significant differences for the path coefficients from achievement to corresponding self-concepts: These were higher for mathematics (Δβ = .09, β = .64) and L1 (Δβ = .10, β = .56) when students were asked about more subjects than just mathematics and L1. Thus, integrating additional subjects led to higher relations between achievement and corresponding self-concept with increased percentages of explained variance (math: R 2 = 5%, verbal: R 2 = 8%). There were no significant differences between the cross-path coefficients, which remained significantly negative.
body_text.section: Inclusion of Additional Subjects in a Study

body_text.text: The moderator gender distribution (k = 139 data sets, n = 260,317 participants) was only related to the magnitude of the path coefficient from achievement to the corresponding self-concept (see Supplemental Table S5 in the online version of the journal), thereby raising the amount of explained variance by R 2 = 5%: The higher the percentage of females, the higher the coefficient. Running the analysis for the subject combination of mathematics and L1 only resulted in lower achievement and self-concept correlations for studies that included more female students.

Data collection revealed k = 130 data sets with n = 535,915 participants. Data sets with samples from the European Union (k = 86) served as the reference group and demonstrated the typical pattern of results supporting the I/E model (see Supplemental Table S6 in the online version of the journal). Similar results emerged for the samples from the United States (k = 16). Samples from Australia (k = 13) showed stronger achievement correlations and (as with the k = 11 Asian samples) higher negative path coefficients from achievement on the noncorresponding self-concept. Region of residence increased the explained variance for achievement correlations by R 2 = 14%, and for cross-domain path coefficients by R 2 = 13% and R 2 = 9%. From South America, there were too few data sets to include these into the analysis (k = 2).

Year of publication (k = 128 data sets, n = 533,711 participants) influenced two effects, leading to a slight increase in the amount of explained variance (R 2 = 9% for achievement correlations, R 2 = 4% for one cross-domain path coefficient). In more recent publications, there were slightly lower achievement correlations, and one smaller negative cross-domain path coefficient (see Supplemental Table  S7 in the online version of the journal). Running these analyses for the subject combination of mathematics and L1 only resulted in slightly lower achievement correlations in more recent publications.

We found k = 168 data sets with n = 572,718 participants. There were slightly stronger achievement correlations (explained variance: R 2 = 6%), and one smaller positive path coefficient from achievement to the corresponding self-concept (R 2 = 7%) for larger samples, whereas one of the two path coefficients from achievement to noncorresponding self-concept indicators (R 2 = 5%) was slightly smaller for larger samples (see Supplemental Table S8 in the online version of the journal). Running these analyses for the subject combination of mathematics and L1 did not reveal any effect of sample size on I/E model relations.

Results showed that the most obvious difference between the two groups of studies was that studies with Herb Marsh as first author or coauthor revealed stronger achievement correlations (r = .71, vs. r = .47; see Supplemental Table  S9 in the online version of the journal). This might be due to the fact that an overproportional number of studies with Herb Marsh used test results as achievement indicators. Moreover, one dimensional comparison effect was slightly stronger in studies with Herb Marsh (Δβ = −.05), whereas the self-concept correlation was slightly weaker (Δr = −.06). Overall, the results indicated generalizability of the positive effects of social and the negative effects of dimensional comparisons across different authors.

The aim of the present study was to test DCT's assumptions and to get a clear picture of the implications of existing research on studies of the I/E and GI/E models by meta-analyzing all existing data sets related to these models. Our metaanalytic path-analyses revealed valuable insights into the effects of social and dimensional comparisons on students' self-concept across various domains. As we have shown, the relations described in the classic I/E model are not restricted to mathematics and L1 but are valid for a broad variety of subject combinations. Taken together, the central assumptions of the classic I/E model were supported for (almost) all analyzed subject combinations: First, the correlations between the achievements in all subjects were significantly positive. Second, they were remarkably stronger than the correlations between the respective self-concepts. Third, the path coefficients from achievements to corresponding self-concepts were substantial and positive for all subjects, indicating social comparison effects. Fourth, for most of the subject combinations, the path coefficients from achievements to noncorresponding self-concepts were significantly negative, indicating contrastive dimensional comparison effects. However, there were important differences with regard to the set of coefficients when various moderators were considered.

One of the most important extensions of the classic I/E model formulated by DCT is the inclusion of subjects other than mathematics and L1, which led us to analyze the effect of different subject combinations and, thereby, the impact of different subject (dis)similarities on dimensional comparison effects. Therefore, we first discuss the effects of subject similarity and subject combinations, in particular, on dimensional comparisons. We then discuss the effects of the additional moderators and specify the DCT assumptions on the contrast and assimilation effects of dimensional comparisons. Second, we refer to social comparisons and the relations between achievements and corresponding self-concepts. Finally, we close with some remarks on the limitations of the present meta-analysis and offer some suggestions for further research on still unresolved questions.

The path coefficients leading from achievement in one subject to self-concept in the other subject were mostly negative. This result clearly supports the main prediction of the GI/E model: that the dimensional comparison effects are stable and generalizable across several subject combinations and samples.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Dimensional Comparison Effects

body_text.text: In the analysis considering mathematics and L1 only, we were able to replicate the negative path coefficients from achievement in one subject on self-concept in the other subject, found in the former meta-analysis. However, significant contrastive dimensional comparison effects were not restricted to the classic mathematics/L1 subject combination, but were also shown in both directions for other subject combinations, such as mathematics/L2, physics/L1, physics/L2, and L2/ L1. Additionally, there were unidirectional negative path coefficients from mathematics and L2 achievement to biology self-concept. The results for the L2/biology relation were in line with our hypothesis (derived from the math-verbal continuum) that far comparisons between one subject of the math/science domain and one subject of the verbal domain would lead to contrast effects. The results are less clear for the mathematics/biology relation. Thus, future research should further pursue the question whether students perceive biology as being closer to the verbal endpoint of the math-verbal continuum than other science subjects, such as physics and chemistry.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Dimensional Comparison Effects

body_text.text: More important for a revision of DCT are the findings regarding the dimensional comparison effects between similar subjects, for which we found lower contrastive or nonsignificant dimensional comparison effects, but no significant assimilation effects. The results for two subjects within the verbal domain (L2/ L1) revealed smaller negative but still significant negative path coefficients on noncorresponding self-concepts. As already noted, subject similarity perceptions trigger differences in self-concepts in the two subjects when experimentally induced (Helm et al., 2016) or reported by students (Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, & Köller, 2006) . The assumption of a correspondence between self-concept correlations and subject similarity is also addressed in a study by Haag and Götz (2012) , who showed that subjects from the math/science domain, like mathematics and physics, are indeed described by students as very similar to each other in relation to various subject characteristics. For example, they are described as dealing with highly difficult connected topics that require a high degree of effort. In addition, verbal domain subjects, like English and German, are characterized as being very similar to each other: They are described, for example, as subjects with an emphasis on the exchange of views on topics that are up-to-date and relevant to daily life. However, students characterized subjects of the math/science and verbal domains as very different from each other.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Dimensional Comparison Effects

body_text.text: Considering these findings and the assumption of the existence of a math-verbal continuum, it might be deduced that students perceive the language subjects as less similar to each other than could be expected in relation to the near-far continuum. We know from psycholinguistic and education research that there are some commonalities between learning and working with languages. For example, Cummins and Swain (1986) define common underlying language proficiencies. From the students' point of view, these commonalities could promote a high perceived similarity of subjects dealing with languages. One explanation for our findings might be that, although both subjects deal with languages, L1 instruction in school seems to be quite different compared with learning L2 in school. Although there are so-called transfer effects between L1 and L2 (Gebauer et al., 2013) , there are on the other hand several differences between different language subjects. In the case of L1 classes, students use the language of instruction at a high proficiency level, whereas with L2 classes, students use the language of instruction at a low proficiency level. This difference in perceived competence levels in speaking the L1 and (different) foreign languages might cause a high perceived dissimilarity between the respective school subjects. Our results show that achieving very well (poorly) in L1 reduces (increases) foreign language selfconcept, and vice versa: This result may be interpreted as supporting the assumption of a high perceived dissimilarity. However, the contrast effects we found for comparisons between verbal subjects were lower than the contrast effects occurring between mathematics and L1. Thus, it can be assumed that students perceive L1 and L2 as rather dissimilar, but not as dissimilar as L1 and mathematics.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Dimensional Comparison Effects

body_text.text: The path coefficients from achievement in one subject of the math/science domain to the self-concept in another subject of that domain were smaller than the path coefficients in combinations of mathematics and L1 or of L1 and L2. Hence, it seems that students perceive math/science domain subjects as more similar to each other than they perceive verbal domain subjects to be. However, the effects were still negative, contradicting findings by Möller, Streblow, Pohlmann, and Köller (2006) , Jansen et al. (2015) , , who found similar small assimilation effects between achievements and academic self-concepts within the math/science domain (e.g., between mathematics and physics). On the other hand, Chiu (2008 Chiu ( , 2012 found contrast effects between mathematics and science. Since Chiu could not differentiate between subject-specific self-concepts in the single science subjects (physics, chemistry, and biology), the dimensional comparison effects may be the result of a mixture of different subjects being perceived as more or less similar. Additionally, when mathematics was compared with biology or physics achievement in our meta-analysis, different dimensional comparison effects emerged: Some of them were negative, some slightly positive. This is supportive of different similarity perceptions for the single-subject combinations. However, the assumption of DCT that dimensional comparisons between two subjects of the math/science domain lead to assimilation effects could not be supported by our analyses as a general rule.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Dimensional Comparison Effects

body_text.text: The results of the analyses based on the aggregation into three (dis)similarity groups generally supported the assumption of differential dimensional comparison effects for subjects supposed to be perceived by students as differentially similar. Whereas achievement correlations were similar for groups with similar and dissimilar subjects, self-concept correlations were significantly lower for the dissimilarity group, and the highest for two subjects of the math/science domain. These higher self-concept correlations between science subjects are accompanied by near-zero dimensional comparison effects between two subjects from the math/science domain. Two possible explanations can be advanced for these near-zero effects: First, students may not conduct dimensional comparisons at all between the two math/science subjects. Second, contrast and assimilation effects may both occur but be similar in size, thus canceling each other out, so that there is no substantial positive or negative net effect on noncorresponding self-concepts. There is a need for additional studies testing whether or not students spontaneously conduct dimensional comparisons between similar subjects, as Möller and Husemann (2006) did in their diary study.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Dimensional Comparison Effects

body_text.text: For the methodological moderators, small effects of years at school, sample size, and publication year were found, which were expressed in smaller contrast effects for younger students, smaller samples, and more recent publications. Moreover, there were stronger contrast effects for studies conducted in Australia and Asia, as well as by Herb Marsh. Dimensional contrast effects were only slightly (not significantly) weaker in elementary school than in secondary school.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Dimensional Comparison Effects

body_text.text: With regard to achievement-self-concept relations within subjects, we found strong indicators of social comparison effects for every subject. The highest path coefficients resulted for mathematics and L2, indicating that the domain-specific self-concept in these subjects strongly depends on scholastic achievement feedback. suggested that the effects of social comparisons are higher for subjects in which students exclusively get feedback at school.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Social Comparison Effects

body_text.text: Path coefficients from achievement to self-concept were particularly strong when grades served as achievement indicators. The moderating effect of the different types of achievement measures was due to the higher correlations between achievements in the math/science and verbal domains. Both achievement indicators may have common domain-unspecific sources, such as cognitive ability or generic achievement motivation. However, objective achievement tests seem to be less domain-specific than teacher-assigned grades, which tend to measure domain-specific ability and motivation components. Since students are much more familiar with their grades than with their results in objective test scores (which, in several studies, such as PISA [Programme for International Student Assessment], they do not even receive), it is not surprising that the grades prompt stronger social comparison effects than do test scores. However, the strong social comparison effects underline the importance of grades for students' expectations.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Social Comparison Effects

body_text.text: A more methodological question is the moderating effect of the inclusion of additional subjects on the paths from achievement to corresponding self-concepts. When students had to evaluate their domain-specific abilities in subjects beyond mathematics and L1, the self-concept indicators were more strongly associated with achievement. Conceivably, this finding may have resulted from the fact that mathematics and L1, as subjects at the end poles of the subject continuum, served as anchors and that the continuum is larger when more subjects in between are dealt with. More research is needed on students' conceptualizations of the subject continuum to further understand such relations. Since the mathematics/L1 achievement correlations were remarkably lower for studies with more subjects, another explanation could be that those studies including additional subjects often used grades rather than test scores as achievement indicators (see below).
body_text.section: Moderators of the Social Comparison Effects

body_text.text: With regard to the students' age, we found support for the assumption of higher path coefficients from achievements to corresponding self-concepts with growing age, indicating more powerful social comparisons when students get older and transition to secondary school.
body_text.section: Moderators of the Social Comparison Effects

body_text.text: As outlined above, this meta-analysis has important theoretical implications for DCT. For reasons of clarity, we summarize them here, before outlining implications for social comparison theory and research. As proposed by the GI/E model, students draw on the performances of their classmates (social comparison) and on their own performances in similar and dissimilar school subjects (dimensional comparisons) as a basis for self-concept formation. According to our results, paths interpreted as social comparison effects are more prominent than paths interpreted as dimensional comparison effects. Within dimensional comparisons, contrast seems to be more prominent than assimilation. As expected, contrasts were strongest for dissimilar subjects. However, contrast was also apparent for comparisons between verbal domain subjects. For most subject combinations within the math/ science domain, neither assimilation nor contrast occurred. Hence, DCT is extended in respect of the following assumption: Comparisons between subjects from the same domain do not yield assimilative dimensional comparison effects-at least, if these are the only subjects considered in the I/E model.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: The extreme domain specificity of academic self-concept, indicated by lower self-concept correlations than achievement correlations, even within the verbal and the math/science domain, has implications for teachers and parents and also for educational practice. Teachers (Helm et al., 2018) as well as parents (Van Zanden et al., 2017) and classmates (Pohlmann et al., 2004) tend to assume that students who are high achieving in one domain will have a positive academic selfconcept in all domains, whereas students who are weak performers in one domain likewise will have poor academic self-concept in all domains. Hence, understanding the implications of research on the (G)I/E model, as in the present study, will allow significant others like teachers and parents to gain a better understanding of students' motivational processes and to infer students' self-concept, for example, more accurately.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: The difficulty for parents and teachers in understanding their children/students correctly may be illustrated by the following example: Our results demonstrated that even high-achieving L2 students may have an average or below-average L2 self-concept. This may seem paradoxical, given their high level of L2 achievement relative to other students, but is explicable in reference to their even better performance in L1 (see Mui et al., 2000; Plucker & Stocking, 2001) . A negative consequence of the use of dimensional comparisons for high-achieving students could be premature specialization in subjects that they perceive to be their superior subjects. Negative attitudes to subjects they experience as intra-individually inferior, and premature termination of their study in these subjects, may also have consequences for high-achieving students.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: In contrast, low-achieving students may have an average or above-average selfconcept in their best language subject. This may seem paradoxical, given their below-average achievement in that subject. A positive consequence of the use of dimensional comparisons for low-achieving students could be a positive attitude and a continuation of their effort to learn in the subject they perceive as superior. For both groups of students, particularly for low-achieving students, a grasp of these principles should help teachers and parents to give positive feedback that is credible to students. Such feedback should help foster students' self-concept.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: One limitation to the generalizability of our results is the cross-sectional character of the primary studies. Self-concept and achievement were treated as having been assessed in single sessions, meaning that we could not focus on longitudinal data. As in the former meta-analysis, this procedure also led to a focus on the effects of achievement on self-concept, whereas the effects of self-concept on achievement were neglected. However, to the present day, we do not have enough longitudinal studies to meta-analyze the I/E model with longitudinal data.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: Meta-analyses have often been criticized for their accumulation of publication bias. However, not all the studies we analyzed presented hypotheses on contrast effects of achievement on noncorresponding self-concepts. Rather, most sought to present estimations of the size of the effects of dimensional comparisons, thus rendering it improbable in this field of research that only significant results should be published. To analyze publication bias, we checked whether sample size, publication year, research group, or country moderated the effects. Whereas sample size, publication year, and authors group did not have strong effects on the reported effect sizes, Australian studies revealed markedly stronger dimensional contrast effects. It is possible that there is an interaction of the country variable with other moderators, leading to stronger contrast effects like subject dissimilarity or use of grades did. However, there were not enough data sets to quantify such an effect.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: We did have enough studies to control for the moderator type of achievement measure when analyzing the effects of dissimilarity (and vice versa) and found evidence for the stability of similarity (achievement measure) effects when type of achievement measure (similarity) was controlled for. This result supports the stability of the similarity effects and also means that the type of achievement measure effect is stable when similarity is controlled for.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: Our meta-analysis was restricted to the academic scholastic domain. It was not possible to include studies dealing with social and dimensional comparisons from other life domains. However, some studies have found that dimensional comparison might also occur in other life domains. For example, Möller and Savyon (2003) found that participants who had just experienced academic failure in an experimental task rated themselves as being more honest than did students who had experienced academic success, indicating that similar dimensional processes of comparison were in operation. Likewise, found support for social and dimensional comparison effects between the personality domains of agency and communion. Furthermore, the effects of social and dimensional comparisons for academic domains are not restricted to school students but can be also found with university students and prospective teachers. Wolff, Helm, Preckel, et al. (2018) found support for the GI/E model in research on university students studying different strands of psychology. In particular, they found dimensional contrast effects between clinical psychology, educational psychology, and work and organizational psychology. Paulick et al. (2017) provided strong support for the capacity of the GI/E model to explain teachers' self-concept, with positive path coefficients from content knowledge and pedagogical content knowledge to corresponding self-concepts, indicating social comparison effects, and negative path coefficients from content knowledge and pedagogical content knowledge to noncorresponding self-concepts, indicating dimensional comparison effects (also see Sorge et al., 2019) .
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: Another limitation is that the meta-analysis did not deal with temporal comparisons that might also affect self-concept. Wolff, Helm, Zimmermann, et al. (2018) , Wolff, Nagy, et al. (2019) , and , in experimental and field studies, analyzed the simultaneous effects of social, temporal, and dimensional comparisons on students' academic self-concepts in various domains. In all studies, social, temporal, and dimensional comparisons showed significant effects on self-concept. For each comparison process, downward comparisons with worse-off standards resulted in higher self-concepts, whereas upward comparisons with better-off standards resulted in lower self-concepts. These results (see also Müller-Kalthoff, are in accordance with the theories underlying social, temporal, and dimensional comparison processes and support their integration into a combined framework, the so-called 2I/E model, as an extension of the classic I/E model that integrates temporal comparisons as a second internal comparison process.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: To sum up, there is very strong support for the GI/E model across different combinations of subjects. The results of our study provided clear support for the generalizability of the GI/E model across different age groups, achievement measure types, countries, and heterogeneous samples. However, it would seem premature to claim that the predicted pattern of results is universal, since relations within the math/science domain are less clear.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research

body_text.text: In conclusion, we can restate the closing sentences of the original meta-analysis, which suggested that there are "only a few studies using longitudinal, experimental, or introspective methods to clarify the antecedents and consequences" , p. 1161 of dimensional comparison processes. Although we believe that the history of self-concept research in psychology is a story of success, we still need further insights into the psychological processes underlying dimensional comparisons.
body_text.section: Implications, Limitations, and Directions for Future Research
